text.headline: Edmonton and the West through the eyes of Gertrude Balmer Watt
text.text:
By Michaela Morrow and Sophie Harvey

Gertrude Balmer Watt () was Edmonton's first female journalist. Her works were published by her husband's newspaper and later collected into two volumes: Town and Trail and A Woman in the West. Her vignettes on daily Edmonton life offer a fascinating glimpse of a growing settler city at the turn of the 20th century. The unique sense of place in Watt's writing was a deliberate choice, as she was interested in documenting "the now" of things. She also added poems, photos, and drawings to enrich her sensory style.

By mapping Watt's colorful writing in the digital realm, we hope to illustrate her life in the same multimedia way she did. In particular, Watt focused on the people, places, and progress made in the newly-anointed City of Edmonton. We wish to explore these three themes as well, asking who and what was in Edmonton at the time, and what a city of progress looked like in the early 1900s.

However, we also want to remind our viewers that Watt was a settler woman with many privileges afforded to her. As with all good historical research, we will be introducing other primary sources to supplement Watt's narratives where we can. Watt was progressive for her time in some ways and drew attention to marginalized narratives herself, but her biases are still firmly apparent. We hope that by drawing from other sources, we will be able to focus on Watt's life as a settler woman with privilege and mobility without sacrificing the context in which she lived and discussed in her own writing.

Without further ado, enjoy the colorful descriptions of Edmonton's past and think about the people, places, and progress of Edmonton shown in Watt's writing.

text.headline: The Lure of the Trail
text.text:
Watt begins Town and Trail with, of course, a narrative about the trail to the "North and West", or what we now call Western Canada:

"Sometimes in the dark moments you ask yourself why should the trail be broken at all? Why is it so imperative that homes all over the face of the earth should be disorganized, that this new and practically unsettled country should be made to blossom like the rose. I think there are two answers: nations, as well as men can not shrink from their destiny, and what should we do with the men who won't fit in, if there were no new worlds to conquer?" (pg. 6)

She continues:

"They want, too, I think I should add, to count for something in this world, to help make history, not just live in it. The lure of the trail has taken men captive from the beginning, and to the end of time those worth while will push on to the lands where a man has elbow room." (pg. 8)

For Watt, becoming a settler was a form of glorious conquest. While we can all agree that the Indigenous lands of Treaty 6, 7, and 8 were not "unsettled" at any point in settler history, her writing reflects the propaganda of the Canadian and British governments, who painted their settlement schemes as a promising new world for the men brave enough to conquer it. While Watt never speaks explicitly negatively about Edmonton and settlers, we will see how her writing takes a more nuanced view as she spends time with Indigenous and other settler groups.

text.headline: "Do You Remember?"
text.text:
In this small vignette, Watt discusses how settlers reminisce about their home countries, whereas she, a woman born in Canada, cannot. She instead focuses on how Edmonton could be remembered as a new home:

"Does any one in Edmonton remember? And if you do not you can, you must, hark back to some corner store— funny, isn't it, what magic lies in the very name, and whenever did a shop in a block or down street reflect one half its glories? — where you disposed, in the days of your youth, of the much prized black coppers, a kind providence sent your way."
Town and Trail pg. 20

media.caption: Coal Mines at Whitemud Creek in Edmonton, 1965

text.headline: On the City Outskirts: Coal Mines, Part 1
text.text:
"If over the sea lies Spain, over the brow of the hill in Edmonton, down on the banks of the river and along the flats, lies a country equally unknown to me. Here it is that the coal camps pitch their tents, the men who haul the sand and gravel erect their homes, and here I found myself one day not long since, a flitter-by in a carriage, barely touching, barely getting a look in at this new phase of life in this wonderful little city of ours but keenly, vitally interested in what I saw."
- Town and Trail, pg. 22

Watt spoke often of the labourers who came to Edmonton. But Watt lived in the city proper, and came from a privileged class--she herself acknowledges she knows little of the city outskirts. This is where the majority of labourers went, particularly if they were of Eastern European, Chinese, or other "second class" ethnic groups of the time. The image above is from the Whitemud Creek coal mines, which would have been one of the most active coal mines outside the "city proper" at the time of Watt's musing. Edmonton's coal mines no longer exist, even as historical landmarks--the pictured coal mine was demolished a few years after the image was taken.

text.headline: Coal Mines, Part 2
text.text:
In her visit to the outskirts, Watt describes how the labourers at the coal mines live a much more miserable life:
"In any or all of these incidents imagination has no need to play a part. But when you come to the modest shacks probably put together by His own hands; when you see a woman scurrying across a break in the fence to borrow her next door neighbor's daily paper, which is probably again passed on to Mrs. Smith; when you have a glimpse through an uncurtained window of lone bachelors frying their solitary rasher of bacon, or seated beside the table, reading by the subdued glow of the little lamp that has to answer for the entire lighting of the house; when you see outside, hanging on the side of the shack, half the paraphernalia of the kitchen; then speculation runs riot. Here you come close to something real, something that tantalizes you into wanting to know more; you begin to realize that there are other things in life than back-biting your dearest friends. It comes to you that existence is after all a solemn thing."
- Town and Trail, pg. 24

According to Edmonton Open Data, Polish workers made up a significant portion of coal mine workers, and Edmonton has the second largest Polish population in Canada. Polish people were excluded from Canadian citizenship and considered foreign workers until BLAH. These are the same "Galicians" Watt mentions at the labour office. This description Watt gives us of how Polish and other workers lived, compared to the much happier description given of visiting British homesteads, highlights the inequality in Canadian land settlement schemes.

With no more coal mines--or monuments to them--in Edmonton, the reminders of what desolate places they created only exist in historical sources. Coal mines are a crucial part of settler history in Western Canada, particularly for Eastern European populations, and it is important to remember that not all Europeans who travelled the Atlantic were treated equally.

text.headline: The Question of the Hour
text.text:
Literacy and Christmas. Find a picture of a bookstore or evidence of Edmonton book presses.
"For this most "peculiar" man then what do I suggest? Verily not a volume of Browning which he is very apt to leave in lonely state on the front parlor table; not an imposssibly gorgeous smoking jacket, not fine brasses and artistic what-nots— but, if he is a man who has a hankering for a well-written book concerning animal life, one of the many much-discussed and oft-attacked yarns that the very wise Thompson-Seton's and Kipling's and Roosevelt's, etc., are turning out in distracting numbers. If he doesn't believe one word that the book says, it gives"him" something to argue about anyway. If he can't rise to animal lore, get him one of the smart toast books that are flooding the market, at any rate something you know he fancies, not something YOU fancy he ought to fancy. " pg. 27

text.headline: The Christmas Entertainment
text.text:
Watt grew up in Eastern Canada and spent much of her early life in Guelph. We interrupt the focus on Edmonton.
"Heavens! the joy of seeing each square blotted out and home and father and mother and the whole precious family so very, very near ! Then comes the excitement of the Christmas concert when "you" speak your piece, fearfully and wonderfully gotten up in your best bib and tucker, starched out of sight, and with enough ribbons to start a notion counter. "Oh, but you just know you'll break down." Yes and dear old mother here all the way from Cherry Hill with a world of love and pride in her eyes, and her heart in her mouth for fear the crowd will make you nervous." pg. 19

text.headline: Canada and Britain
text.text:
" We do not expect nor wish to have Canadians slavish imitators of the people of Great Britain. The character of our vast domain and of all the influences which go to make us a nation must necessarily be impressed upon us. But with all due respect to Mr. Begbie, we do admire the little island across the sea, both in its present and in the past, and we have a real feeling of loyalty towards it and towards its Sovereign, which is also our Sovereign. The rapidity with which new-comers among our citizens from other than British countries enter into these feelings of ours is a matter for wonder. In another part of this volume I have pointed out how heartily the children, drawn seemingly from all parts of the earth, enter into the spirit of our patriotic celebrations." pg. 36

Here Watt is celebrating the diversity of Canada. In this paper, she refutes the idea that Canada is a lawless land because of its increasing distance from Britain, replying to a letter from BLAH.

text.headline: The Men Who Make Good
text.text:
"the right men set to their task soberly, with stout hearts, and in time I see a snug farm house, many cattle and great wheat fields, all, all the gift of this wonderful new Dominion. While the other set of men are loafing about town, demanding "where are the brass beds and the parlor rockers?"" (pg . 41)

Watt compares the pioneers to those who have come to Canada for "urban" life, relating to an experience in Vancouver.

text.headline: A Western Salon
text.text: Watt visited many establishments run by people considered second class citizens at the time. One of those is " Song Lee's little Chinese restaurant around the corner", which according to Simon Fraser University was possibly the only Chinese restaurant in Edmonton at the time. Watt describes restaurant crowds as people made up of many different backgrounds--ethnicities, jobs, and history do not matter in the (overly utopian) vision Watt portrays. (pg. 43).

media.caption: An image of the Alberta Legislature Buildings taken from across the river, ca. 1913

text.headline: Polly Hears of the Opening of the Alberta Legislature
text.text:
"In a little glass box at the side of the house where some one banished the Lieut.-Governor while the Speaker did his little stunt, I saw a vast collection of military-aries, doing goodness knows what, and serving, as far as I could learn, absolutely no purpose. But they seemed to like it, and what harm did it do?

Leaving the hall I couldn't help my scattering thoughts flying across seas to the suffragettes in the old land.

Good-gracious is it to take part is such proceedings as these that a goodly number of fair agitatresses are now languishing behind the bars? Is it to oust such placidly, capable, good-natured creatures as the occupants of these soft-seated chairs I had just left, that woman, lovely woman is shouting herself hoarse in the foggy little island across the pond, or is it for the pure joy of occupying the centre of the stage where the calcium shines and figuring in an heroic scene encircled by the arms of a fine stalwart "bobby?"--(arms and the men are, I understand, scarce commodities across the sea) it is to wonder."

This text is from a fake letter written between two sisters about the opening of the Edmonton Legislative Grounds. In it, we see Watt take a dismissive attitude to both the grandstanding men of government and the suffragettes wishing to become like them. Women eventually gained the right to vote in Alberta in 1916, nine years after this was written. The letter offers an interesting opposition to suffragettes--mainly in its suggestion that the government is made up of grandstanding individuals more interested in attention than responsibility, and so suffragettes must be clamoring for the same reasons. Such a view, while perhaps disagreeable in the modern day, does show the complexity of the suffragette movement in Canada, as well as certain attitudes to the settler governments of the time.

text.headline: Suffragettes
text.text: Not all women shared Watt's views, of course. In the same year, 1907, Henrietta Muir Edwards made a rousing speech at a social event in Edmonton demanding Albertan women be allowed to vote. She is credited with sparking the fire of activism in Edmonton and its surrounding areas. It is important to note that, at this time, suffragettes were made up of white women. Indigenous, Asian, and other women discriminated against in Canadian governance would not gain the right to vote until years, sometimes decades, later.
